video.title: Rust Programming Course for Beginners - Tutorial
video.description:
Learn the Rust programming language in this course for beginners.

✏️ Shaun Hamilton created this course.

💻 Rust Template used in video: https://replit.com/@Sky020/Rust-Template?v=1

⭐️ Resources ⭐️
🔗 Slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1k2kPfrLunscHV4n-4IoC3D78dNR6R1Rhdi039PCG-Wk/edit?usp=sharing
🔗 Article version: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/rust-in-replit/
🔗 Rust in Replit Course: https://replit.com/github/freeCodeCamp/Rust-in-Replit

Thanks to Replit for providing a grant that made this course possible.

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Course Introduction
⌨️ (01:16) Rust Overview
⌨️ (02:00) Initialising the CLI Calculator
⌨️ (04:25) Handling Environment Arguments
⌨️ (09:00) Understanding the nth Method
⌨️ (16:00) Parsing Strings into Floats
⌨️ (18:05) Declaring a Function
⌨️ (18:30) If Statements
⌨️ (21:20) Implicit Returns
⌨️ (22:25) Parsing String into Char
⌨️ (23:20) Formatting Output
⌨️ (25:20) Match Control Flow
⌨️ (27:05) Panicking!
⌨️ (28:30) Building a Release
⌨️ (29:30) Initialising the Image Combiner
⌨️ (30:00) Creating Args Module
⌨️ (31:08) Structs
⌨️ (32:30) Declaring the New Module
⌨️ (33:20) Private vs Public
⌨️ (34:30) Implementing the New Function
⌨️ (36:40) Deriving the Debug Trait
⌨️ (37:40) Using get_nth_arg in Struct
⌨️ (38:57) External Crates
⌨️ (39:52) Decoding Images
⌨️ (43:15) Destructuring Tuples
⌨️ (43:56) Importing Missing Types
⌨️ (44:35) Handling Format Errors with Result
⌨️ (46:00) Enums
⌨️ (47:20) Resizing Images
⌨️ (55:00) FloatingImage Struct
⌨️ (56:35) Buffers with Vecs
⌨️ (58:15) TryInto Conversions
⌨️ (1:00:05) Deriving Debug for Enums
⌨️ (1:00:40) Running the Code with Images
⌨️ (1:02:25) Combining the Image Pixels
⌨️ (1:11:20) Understanding Borrows and References
⌨️ (1:12:15) Creating Methods
⌨️ (1:15:20) Error Propagation
⌨️ (1:15:53) Saving the New Image
⌨️ (1:17:30) Using the Image Combiner
⌨️ (1:18:20) Better Error Handling

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Emanuel Czirai
topLevelComment.text:
1:19:57 I notice this is idiomatic Rust to NOT tell the exact path of/or the filename when this kind of read(or not found) error happens :)) So what you see is: Error: UnableToReadImageFromPath(Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" })
Now it's up to the user to GUESS which filename was not found (in this case, either the first one or the second one, but imagine this happens in a big project). This is literally the reason I stopped trying to learn Rust a few year ago!

topLevelComment.author: Niz
topLevelComment.text:
This tutorial went from being a beginner friendly slow paced to one huge mess when it came to the image combiner.

Image combiner protion should have been devided,  it's hard to follow along since we are seeing no output but keep adding code...

But really Thank you for this. Really interesting stuff.

topLevelComment.author: ajitabhs

replies.author: Shaun Hamilton
replies.text:
Hello there,
Relevant question. The difference is each time the `get_nth_arg` function is called, it calls the `nth` method on a new instance of `args`. More specifically, a different reference is used, therefore there is no reference to a mutated variable between calls.

topLevelComment.author: hr3nk
topLevelComment.text: I am really new to Rust, but the last part of the video on the alternative way to work with Result and Option by using match operator and if statement doesn't seem really "clean" to me. It creates a big amount of nested stuff, which is pretty hard to read. Maybe the problem is in the function itself, considering it is doing three things: opens file, loads it into memory and determines format. My OOP brain screams to split this functionallity and probably move to a separate entity, smth like ImageLoader. As for other stuff, awesome tutorial!

topLevelComment.author: imadetheuniverse4fun
topLevelComment.text: The nth unwrap situation in the beginning isn't explained well at all. You gave the solution to call nth(0) on the second and third arguments but with zero explanation of why. It doesn't make any sense...

topLevelComment.author: Skoozle
topLevelComment.text: hey is the mic in another room there lads? haha :)

topLevelComment.author: Funny News
topLevelComment.text: how about building a backend api with rust and postgress?

topLevelComment.author: HellEye
topLevelComment.text: I was all on board with rust (zero experience but I'm pretty alright with a few other languages) until there was an unwrap hell case towards the end. Is there any better way to handle that specific case of potentially having 3 different errors from 3 different places? I assume there's no try-catch block, I just don't want to have 4 levels of indentation for an 8 line function.

replies.author: Sky020
replies.text:
Personally, I have not found many cases where I end up nesting to an uncomfortable degree.
However, you can avoid this, by querying the variants: https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/#querying-the-variant

That is, you can return early when `is_err()` or `is_none()` return true.

topLevelComment.author: chinpokomon_
topLevelComment.text:
the craziest thing is that now i can appreciate rust for its design. a few years ago i would consider it a form of torture. 



basically, you spend all of that time writing it to not have to endlessly debug it afterwards. it is also quite expressive, so it is easier to understand someone else's code

topLevelComment.author: Thomas T.
topLevelComment.text: Honestly that’s the worst course I’ve ever watched. In the first minutes there are introduced so many terms that for the beginners are simply impossible to grasp if you haven’t got previous strong programming background. “Oh that’s struct, that’s uname, that’s macro,that’s Some, that’s unwrapping, thats mutable, that’s self reference” in what, 2min? There is no explanation at all what we try to achieve in each step, jumping across various features of the language. Upon almost every execution there is always some error forcing a viewer to swap the thinking from what we were trying to achieve to why the code is wrong again. I applaud the intentions but disappointed.

replies.author: Shaun Hamilton
replies.text:
Hello there,
Relevant question. The difference is each time the `get_nth_arg` function is called, it calls the `nth` method on a new instance of `args`. More specifically, a different reference is used, therefore there is no reference to a mutated variable between calls.

topLevelComment.author: Chaotic Mind of Mike
topLevelComment.text: I really wish you wouldn't teach people to ignore errors and unwrap directly. You could be using proper error handling on those nth calls instead. Bad habits stick.

replies.author: Chaotic Mind of Mike
replies.text: @Shaun Hamilton introducing the bad habits in the first place is something to be avoided. I've watched decades of programming examples without proper error handling and it's caused immeasurable harm to programming habits.

topLevelComment.author: Artem unknown
topLevelComment.text: Don't you think that 1.5 hours are quite insufficient to uncover all the Rust's topics? There are too many things to talk about. Anyway, thank you very much for you work!

replies.author: Shaun Hamilton
replies.text:
Hello there,
Yes, 1.5 hours is very little time to cover all Rust's topics. However, this is a Beginners Rust Course. So, I did not expect to cover all the topics. Also, most of the learning can happen in the interactive curriculum linked in the description, which takes much longer than 1.5 hours.

I hope you managed to learn something, though :)

topLevelComment.author: Eqofriendly Friendly
topLevelComment.text:
Hey! Would you recommend me learning Rust after considering that I wanna focus developing my career?

Also, I've done rust for about four days. 

If possible, please tell me how to take inputs from space separated values? Like for example, if a user gives 2 test cases and for each one, he gives values of
5 10 15 "Hello" "World" -> five inputs
50 20 "goodnight" "kid" -> four inputs

replies.author: kaby
replies.text: You can take inputs from space separated values within a two quotes by using the "shell-words" crate

replies.author: Jatin Dua
replies.text:
@Hermes I've passed my high school few months ago and I'm in college rn so I thought it's a good time to get my hands on Rust in order to go deep in the programming concepts :)
Hope I won't regret my decision

replies.author: Whaling With Ishmael
replies.text: I would advise against it. From my understanding Rust isn’t nearly as popular as a lot of other languages like Python, JavaScript and even C++. If there’s a specific job you’re targeting, or if there’s a lot of jobs for Rust developers in your area then I’d say go for it. But otherwise I’d say look for the jobs in your area. See which languages are most in demand and then learn those languages. Probably just the very most popular one actually. That’s my two sense anyways. Good luck

replies.author: Dave Redacted
replies.text: @SomeAbsolutelyRandomStuff Disagree. Learn Rust if you want to, especially if you already have a job as different kind of programmer. As for getting a job with Rust, don't expect anything anytime soon, but don't think it'll just vanish- everyone said python would be a stupid toy language for a decade and a half, now look at it. Rust is building the same kind of momentum and has a lot of support from major players.

topLevelComment.author: Shawn Mitchell
topLevelComment.text: why do we need to escape the asterisk character?

replies.author: Shaun Hamilton
replies.text: In most shells, the asterisk is a wildcard (special syntax interpreted by the shell). Specifically, the asterisk is used to represent zero or more characters (much the same way it does in RegEx). So, the interpreter needs to be told not to treat the asterisk as a wildcard, by escaping it. Hope this helps
